channel.title: Resources on Carleton Computer Science Society
channel.description: Recent content in Resources on Carleton Computer Science Society

item.title: Making a Balanced Course Schedule
item.description: Careful planning can help you create a timetable that supports your academic goals, fits your lifestyle, and keeps your workload manageable.

item.title: Which Electives Should You Take?
item.description: There are a lot of options for Computer Science students to explore electives that match their interests, fulfill degree requirements, and even help complete a minor.

item.title: Which courses can I take as electives?
item.description: You can take any course offered at Carleton as an elective, except for a few prohibited courses.

item.title: Are all sections of a course the same?
item.description: All sections cover the same content, but there may be minor differences such as the instructor, schedule and more.

item.title: Are COMP 1005/1006 and 1405/1406 different?
item.description: COMP 1005/1006 and 1405/1406 have the exact same content. CS students should register in COMP 1405/1406.

item.title: Can I switch courses after registering?
item.description: You can switch courses until the first few weeks of the term

item.title: Can I take second year courses in first year?
item.description: You may be able to take some 2000+ level courses if you meet the prerequisites

item.title: Do I have to take first year courses in a specific order?
item.description: COMP 1405 and 1406 should be taken in Fall and Winter respectively. Other first-year core courses can be taken in either term.

item.title: Do we register for both fall and winter courses now?
item.description: Yes, you should register for both terms as soon as your time ticket opens to secure the classes you want.

item.title: How many courses should I take in a semester?
item.description: Full-time students generally take 2.5 credits per term, but it’s also common to take fewer courses for a lighter workload.

item.title: Should I take STAT 2507 in first year?
item.description: Taking STAT 2507 in your first year can help ease the workload of your second year, due to the large number of required 2000 level courses.

item.title: Should You Take COMP 1405/1406-Z?
item.description: Taking the accelerated COMP 1405 Z section enables you to take 2000-level COMP courses earlier, but it’s not necessarily the right choice for everyone.

item.title: Ways to Reduce Your Second Year Workload
item.description: Strategically selecting courses in your first year can help reduce your second-year workload and set you up for academic success.

item.title: What is an override request?
item.description: An override request is used to request permission to register in a course that you aren’t eligible to take.

item.title: What is the difference between a lecture and tutorial?
item.description: Lectures are where instructors cover course content, while tutorials provide extra practice and support.

item.title: What is the difference between scheduled and unscheduled courses?
item.description: Scheduled courses have lectures at specific times. Unscheduled courses provide lecture recordings instead of having live lectures.

item.title: When can I register for courses?
item.description: Check your time ticket in Carleton Central to find out when you can start registering for courses.

item.title: Which courses should I take in first year?
item.description: There are 5 courses all Computer Science students should take in their first year. Depending on your stream, there may be a few more.

item.title: Who should I contact if I need help with registration?
item.description: Contact the academic advisors at scs.ug.advisor@carleton.ca

item.title: Why are some courses listed without instructors?
item.description: Some teaching assignments may be finalized closer to the start of the term. Don’t wait until an instructor is assigned to register.

item.title: Why You Should Consider a Minor as a CS Student
item.description: Instead of just filling elective credits with bird courses, using them toward a minor can help you stand out, deepen your skills, and explore a second area of interest.

item.title: What is the COMP 1405/1406-Z section?
item.description: The Z section is an accelerated course that combines the content of COMP 1405 and COMP 1406 into a single term.

item.title: Course Registration
What is a Breadth elective vs a Free elective?
item.description: Breadth Electives cannot be under COMP, MATH, STAT, CSEC, DATA or Engineering. Free Electives can be from any department.
